report.summary: branch 3.5.0, gradlew build fails due to checksum failure
report.label: None yet
report.description:
Verifying org.whispersystems:textsecure-android
FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.
* What went wrong: A problem occurred configuring root project 'Signal-Android'. > Checksum failed for org.whispersystems:textsecure-android:a08cdd73aaaca6d3e868a93522c02d6a159551735f7048b1f3a53582e10c8ec2
* Try: Run with --stacktrace option to get the stack trace. Run with --info or --debug option to get more log output.
BUILD FAILED This appears to be related to an update of org.whispersystems.textsecure-android from 1.8.2 to 1.8.3 (as listed in build.gradle). On branch master, build.gradle still lists textsecure-android:1.8.2, and contains the correct checksum for that version.

report.summary: Wording: 'voice notes' vs. 'voice messages'
report.label: None yet
report.description: Regarding the recent commit 1323b49: Are you sure you want to use the term "voice notes"? When I google this term, I'm getting results like http://www.guidingtech.com/44248/voice-notes-android/, where a voice note is a note to oneself in the sense of a dictating machine. "voice messages" would be more appropriate imho. I can do a PR changing this if you want me to (a freebie of course).

report.summary: Send Multiple Images at Once
report.label: None yet
report.description: Feature Request: The ability to send multiple images at once. Right now, you can only send one image at once. Telegram allows the user to send unlimited images at once.

report.summary: Add Encrypted SMS between Signal users.
report.label: None yet
report.description: There should really be an option to send encrypted SMS instead of solely relying on an internet connection for encrypted chat. I mean, it's definitely possible between Signal users. The problem arises when one party does not have an internet connection, but both parties have a mobile signal. You have to resort to insecure SMS in order to get a message through. This shouldn't be the case. Between signal users, it should seamlessly be able to switch between secure SMS and secure IM when available.

report.summary: Lock messages when screen is locked.
report.label: None yet
report.description: Add an option so that the messages are locked, if enabled, when the screen is locked, instead of relying on a timer.

report.summary: Voice notes created with MIME type audio/*
report.label: None yet
report.description: I just installed the new 3.5.0 beta and tried out the new voice message function. Receiving a voice message on iOS, I get "Received unsupported attachment type.". I think this is due to https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/blob/master/src/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/mms/AudioSlide.java#L38 where "audio/*" is explicitly set. If we would use "audio/amr" this would be matched by the MIME types in https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-iOS/blob/master/Signal/src/util/MIMETypeUtil.m#L15

report.summary: Voice messages are trimmed
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have found something pretty annoying when recording voice messages. The last half a second or so always gets trimmed. My understanding is that the recording must be a multiple of 1 second, so if you record for 8.4 seconds you will lose the last 0.4 seconds. I don't have sound evidence for this but after several attempts it looks like it (or maybe it's just my imagination but the fact remains that I can't hear the last word I say in most messages). Android 4.1 Signal 3.5

report.description: The new voice message can be recorded and sent even after leaving a group. The remaining group members also receive the message. However those can't be sent, because they require clicking the send button.

report.summary: Problems with messages from unknown contact.
report.label: None yet
report.description: With signal 3.5.0 I get the following issue: Somebody who is not in my contact list sends me a push message. Two issues arise: Although he is using Signal for iOS I cannot respond to the message with an encrypted call (padlock symbol next to phone symbol is missing). The padlock symbol appears when I go into the new message screen and pull down the contact list to refresh the push information. I then have a conversation with the person via push messaging and later add him to my contact list. Some time after I add him I get a push notification stating "... is now on Signal, say hey!", although the contact was Signal user before he first contacted me.

report.summary: A lot of translatable messages have linebreaks that seem unnecessary
report.label: None yet
report.description: A lot of translatable messages have linebreaks that seem unnecessary. As just a few examples: registration_progress_activity__your_device_needs_network_connectivity registration_progress_activity__no_network_connectivity registration_progress_activity__waiting_for_sms_verification registration_activity__your_country_code_and_phone_number There are dozens of others. Are these linebreaks actually useful for how the app runs, or are they there just to keep the line lengths in res/values/strings.xml under a certain limit? If it's the latter, then maybe they should be removed, because when translating in Transifex, they appear in a rather weird way, and the Transifex interface sometimes complains that they are not translated correctly, even when it appears completely artificial.

report.summary: Generally poor audio quality and high latency with Signal calls
report.label: None yet
report.description: Latency: Perhaps the most notable difference between making a Signal and a standard cell phone call is the latency encountered. In fact, it was the very first comment one of my friends mentioned when we initiated the call. RTT appears to be at least 1 second even when the person I'm calling is relatively close (several hundred miles on the East cost of the US, where Signal has a server - can't find the link now but Moxie published a blog post indicating where Signal has servers for routing calls). However, when I call the same person on Jitsi, the RTT is below 100 ms, and latency is barely noticeable. We are both connecting via Wifi using broadband connections with at least 50 Mbit down and 10 Mbit of upload capacity for him and 100/100 for me (Fiber on my end, cable on his). Jitsi shows effectively 0% packet loss and sub 5ms jitter with RTT typically around 50 ms. Thus, I would not expect significant latency in Signal given our geographic proximity and high speed, relatively low-latency connections. In fact, my Signal calls to the US from China seemed to have similar latency to the East Cost - East Coast US calls. Audio Quality: The audio quality in Signal appears to generally be worse than a cell phone call, and is significantly worse than Jitsi or Skype (both of which use wideband codecs - SILK for Skype IIRC and Opus @ 48 Khz for Jitsi). In addition, I notice more cut-outs and audio distortions with Signal. Again, both callers are on Wifi with high-speed broadband connections and are in relatively close physical proximity. I would imagine that implementing Opus in Signal would improve call quality generally, particularly if it is allowed to run in a wideband setting, as Opus is superior to Speex at all bitrates/sampling rates per the documentation. However, I'm rather perplexed about the subjectively high latency. Note: Wasn't sure whether to post this here or on the mailing list. Please advise.

report.summary: PNG -> scaled JPEG attachment -> saves with ".png" extension
report.label: None yet
report.description: When sending a media message with a PNG attachment, Signal converts the PNG to JPEG (and scales it) before sending. Later, when choosing to save the image from the conversation, this JPEG is saved with a ".png" extension. This occurs because Attachment#updateAttachmentData replaces the attachment data stream without updating the attachment content type. Steps to reproduce Take a completely unamusing screenshot (PNG) to send to a contact Open Signal Open the conversation with said contact Tap the Attach button Tap the Image button Select the new screenshot from the documents provider Observe the draft media message with thumbnail Tap the Send button Wait for the media message progress to complete (converting to JPEG, scaling, sending) Long press the media message Tap the Save button Reluctantly embrace the security warning Observe the new Signal-yyyy-mm-dd-hhmmss.png in /sdcard/Pictures adb pull this curious file and check check it Behold, a JPEG in disguise Device info: Nexus 5, stock Android 6.0 MRA58K, Signal 3.5.0 (473e470) App state: Signal registered, SMS enabled, default SMS app

report.summary: Bad UX with expiring Signal versions
report.label: None yet
report.description: Signal can literally expire any second, so that out of a sudden you are not able to send messages anymore (well, of course only if you do not update it for 90 days). Immediately updating the app right then might not be possible if you require a wifi connection. I am sure that this is not a problem for any of the people involved here, but for other non tech-savvy users it can be (firsthand experience). Reasons for apps not updating automatically: new permission required (happened before the RedPhone integration) not enough free space on the device available for some other reason... it is not uncommon for me to see 10 or so pending app updates on other peoples's devices There should be a time-triggered warning, or some other trigger to inform the user beforehand.

report.summary: Play store description is not translatable
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hi, I couldn't find where can translate the description of the app for Play store. For example, if the app is viewed in the Play store in Hebrew, then the short description is shown in machine translation, which is incorrect, and makes it hardly possible to understand what the app is, because it auto-translates the word "Signal" to a Hebrew word that is unrelated to the actual app's name, and makes several grammatical mistakes. That's how machine translations usually are. The long description with a list of features is shown in English, without any translation. The solution is to let the translators at Transifex translate these descriptions. That's how it's done for the Wikipedia app, for example, and it works well.

report.summary: Removing call entries from a conversation should be possible
report.label: None yet
report.description: I can remove a complete conversation, including text messages and entries for accepted/missed calls in it. I can also remove single text messages from a conversation. However, I cannot remove just (single or all) call entries from a conversation, which I would have expected to be possible. I rarely delete a complete conversation, as there usually are some messages in it that I still want to keep. This currently implies that I also have to keep all call entries, which is slightly annoying, as they contain practically no information. In my opinion, to make removing call entries possible, there should be at least one of the following features: I should be able to select and remove call entries just like text messages. I should be able to "lock" text messages so they are not removed when I delete the conversation. (This is currently on Signal 3.6.1 on Android.)

So, these in-thread notifications should be silenced as well in "Priority" mode since they are not priority notifications. To clarify, the android priority setting works for the other notifications from the Signal app; the issue only affects the "in-thread" notifications. I am using Signal 3.6.1 on Android 5.1.1. I have an LG Nexus 4 device with T-Mobile USA as the carrier.

report.summary: Add delivery date/time for outgoing SMS/Signal messages info
report.label: None yet
report.description: Feature proposal: Add delivery date/time for outgoing SMS/Signal messages in "message details". In a similar way that we can see when the incoming message was both sent and delivered in the "message details" dialog, add this functionality to the outgoing messages. Right now, only "sent" date/time is shown there. Regarding privacy implications - this will not change anything there, no extra info is required from the recipient to provide. Just present the already non-secret "second checkmark's timestamp" in a more convenient way to the user (via "message details" dialog). Just as the "second checkmark" itself, the usability of this if obvious, especially if a contact in a bad reception area and you don't get the "second checkmark" right away. For SMS, this functionality is provided by most SMS apps if "delivery receipts" are enabled. So in a way, using Signal as SMS client in current form reduces this sms functionality (so for SMS case it might as well be considered as a bug).

report.summary: RCS-e integration
report.label: None yet
report.description: Signal should incorporate sending messages via RCS-e. SMS integration is already awesome. RCS-e is being pushed as the next generation messaging protocol by some telecommunication providers but they are all lacking a good app to use the service. Signal could make use of an existing RCS-e service (already present on some devices) or get an option to download the generic RCS-e service APK by the GSMA. Integration guides are readily available. 👍 6

report.summary: Change 'TextSecurePlaintextBackup.xml' to 'SignalPlaintextBackup.xml'
report.label: None yet
report.description: This is a small change, but it should improve user experience. I can imagine that it is confusing, especially for new users who don't know that Signal was called TextSecure before, to find out that your Signal plaintext backups are saved to a file called TextSecurePlaintextBackup.xml. Looking at the code, PlaintextBackupImporter.java should probably keep looking for TextSecurePlaintextBackup.xml (besides the new SignalPlaintextBackup.xml) for backward compatibility.

report.summary: Feature Request: Nicknames in groups
report.label: None yet
report.description: When joining a new group it's sometimes hard to find out which people belong to which phone number. Asking everyone in the group who they are is tedious. It would be nice to be able to set a nickname in the app, that's sent in an extra field in each group message. The receiving clients could show this nickname if the number has no associated contact. Setting a nickname would of course be optional and the nickname is only sent in group messages. Other messengers support this as well and it's very useful to find out who the person is that just sent a message in a group. 👍 2

report.summary: Proposal: GIPHY Support
report.label: None yet
report.description: While Signal currently supports GIFs, it requires storing them on your local device (which is annoying). Since GIPHY has an API for searching GIFs, it should be plausible to implement a client-side feature where the client finds a GIF using GIPHY and then sends it without saving it locally (or temporarily saving it). The only issue I can see is that GIPHY would be told that a particular person is a Signal user.

report.summary: Exclude meaning rich colors for conversation differentiation initially
report.label: None yet
report.description: I installed Signal on Android and very shortly after got messages from two friends who both use Signal congratulating me on installing it. The two conversations were colored primary red and primary green. I assumed that these colors signified some meaning about the conversations like maybe the green one was secure and the red one was insecure. I did some Googling and found Issue #945 which seemed to imply that the issue color indicated the transport medium that the message arrived by. I asked @mfb and he figured out what was going on, that these colors were meant to differentiate conversations from each other. I'd like to recommend / feature request, excluding meaning rich colors from use as differentiating conversation colors, at least initially, to avoid confusing the user. If for example the first two conversations were in pastels or in pretty much any two colors other than red and green (which have a very strong visual meaning of stop/go success/error good/bad) I think I would have begun to intuit that the colors were for conversation differentiation. I'd also say that if it started out with pastels or some other non-meaning-rich colors and I later encountered red and green conversations I'd probably intuit they were just there for differentiation. Since it looks like conversation color is driven directly by the contacts name I'm not sure it would make sense to tweak the initial colors as the user begins using the app. Since, by my read, of the list of colors, only red and green have a strong meaning. All the others seem not meaning rich to me, maybe just remove red and green. Problem there is that existing users mapping of which conversations have which colors would change, possibly confusing people. So, hopefully someone here has a better idea of a solution here than what I've come up with.

report.summary: Allow the choice of font size for chat screen
report.label: None yet
report.description: Allow the choice of font size for chat screen : either exact size in points or simply small-medium-large will likely be more than enough. It's a basic option supported by most messengers - even by the stock sms client ! I have a 6" smartphone and the standard font size is way too large for my screen, which could easily and usefully fit much more text. Others, e.g. those with poor eyesight or those with small screens, might find the standard font size too small to read comfortably. I believe this would be a useful feature and one that's probably pretty straightforward to implement. 👍 1

report.summary: Consider SMS spam blocking features
report.label: None yet
report.description: Signal is my favourite application for both SMS and encrypted messaging. However given the fact that SMS spam is on the rise, It would be a very useful feature to support some sms spam blocking. There are many third party application that do this but they require changing the default SMS application. I think any of the following features would be useful: Options to only issue a notification for messages from known contacts. Word based classification/blacklists (perhaps with an option to never block messages from known contacts) Number blacklists (arguably easy for spammers to circumvent) Of course there are more sophisticated options as well, but these may provide the greatest bang for buck.

report.summary: Prefill registration form with user's phone number (no need for manual input)
report.label: None yet
report.description: During registration (just after installation) the user has to enter its phone number manually. The national code (e.g. +49 is prefilled). This is not optimal because: Users are (psychologically) relactant to (actively) enter personal data like phone number that is sent to some server (which they've just heard about somewhere). So I've really seen friends aborting the registration at this very step. This is really a UX issue. It's about 9 unnessary keystrokes more At least in Europe people mess up with the leading 0 in phone numbers. A lot of people without internatinal relations do not know (or at least are puzzled about) that the leading 0 is to be ignored after the internal code of +49 Would be good if the users phone number could be automatically retrieved from the phone by Signal and the number prefilled into the input form. A user could still change the prefilled number just in case.

report.summary: Registration does not offer a call-first verification
report.label: None yet
report.description: Per documentation, the user is unable to get a call-first registration. This alienates users who use calling-only cell plans where sending and receiving texts is possible but costs money. A simple solution would be to add a "call me instead" button to the bottom left of the "Connect With Signal" prompt, which immediately calls the user. This would allow those users to use Signal while causing no friction to anyone else. Side note: Although I do not know for sure, I believe the iOS app behaves in the same way. Can anyone else confirm?

report.summary: Senders name doesn't update after adding to contacts
report.label: None yet
report.description: If you are in a group conversation and receive a message from an unkown contact, the sender is displayed as a number. report.summary: Direct capture front camera preview different compared to taken picture
report.label: None yet
report.description: When taking a picture with the front camera using direct capture in collapsed state the resulting image is different compared to the preview. The preview shows the lower portion from a full screen capture, while the resulting image is from the middle portion of a full screen capture. I will try to explain the issue with an image series. The first one is an image of the phone with the camera preview. Note the detail marked with the red circle in the upper right corner. The next one is the preview of the taken picture. Note the detail mentioned before is now in the lower left corner. I wanted to take a screenshot from the camera preview but strangely the screenshot shows the view like for the taken picture. This is why the first pictures a not screenshots. See the third picture. The last image is a full screen capture of the same scene. I suppose the region in the camera preview is different to the final region applied. This happens only with the front camera using direct capture in collapsed state. The back camera works as expected. Device info: Samsung Galaxy S5 Mini, Stock Android 4.4.2, Signal 3.8.1 Debug log: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/b3bc25fd68eb6fc8bec2

report.summary: Signal cannot connect even though it just did

The connect to server (to request an SMS) succeeds. Then SMS arrives and Signal goes on to generate keys. When that finishes, which is really quick, it complains about not being able to connect to the server. Wait, what? It can contact the servers to send an SMS but is then unable to contact the server? report.summary: Disconcerting 'X is on Signal, say hey!' notifications
report.label: None yet
report.description: I'm submitting this report on behalf of a concerned friend. Their phone is setup in such a way that many of the contacts stored in the phone are not to be contacted directly (i.e. via the phone number registered with WhisperSystems). These contacts are only to be contacted via some off channel (email, other phone, etc). Anyways, upon installing or updating (I don't recall which it was) to the latest version of Signal, they received a number of 'X is on Signal, say hey!' notifications. Obviously this was very disconcerting, as the first thought was that people on the other end might be receiving similar notifications. Is that the case, or are they "one-way" in the sense that you only receive notifications for numbers that you already have in your contacts? Surely Signal isn't leaking contact details to third-party users... This seemed to be very un-Signal like behavior and the person in question was concerned enough to consider discontinuing use of the app. I wanted to find out more regarding this behavior beforehand, as this issue is very unclear. Perhaps there is some way to opt-out of this (or preferably make it opt-in)? Some clarification would be much appreciated! Thanks for the awesome product by the way.

report.summary: Signal location messages fail to auto-snap to more precise locations
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hi, Signal 3.9.0 introduces location messages. While generating such a location message the phone starts GPS service of the device. Typically position precision increases after several seconds in several steps. But Signal stays at the very first (inaccurate) position. Other messengers like Telegram keep track on position updates and always auto-snap to the newest (typically most accurate) position. In Signal I have to press the center button several times before sending the location message in order to send an exact position. It would be great if Signal supports auto-snap like other messengers.

report.summary: Turkish description of the Signal app for Android
report.label: None yet
report.description: Signal gizliliği kolaylaştırır. Ücretsiz Metin mesajları, Resimler ve Grup mesajları gönderin! Gizlilik mümkün, Signal bunu kolaylaştırır. Signal kullanarak, SMS ücreti ödemeden anında iletişim kurabilir, grup oluşturarak aynı anda tüm arkadaşlarınızla gerçek zamanlı olarak sohbet edebilir ve tam bir gizlilik altında medya paylaşımı yapabilirsiniz. Sunucunun iletişiminize erişimi yoktur ve sizinle ilgili herhangi bir veriyi asla depolamaz. ★ İstediğini söyle. Signal her zaman, her mesaj için gizlilik sağlayan uçtan uca gelişmiş bir şifreleme protokolü kullanır. ★ Özgür ve açık kaynak yazılım. Herkese, Signal'in güvenliğini doğrulamak için kodu denetleme olanağı sağlar. Signal, mesajlarınızı güvenli tutmak için şifreleme protokolleri kullanan açık kaynak kodlu tek uygulamadır. ★ Kendin ol - Signal mevcut telefon numaranı ve adres defterini kullanır. Hesabını yönetmek için ayrı olarak oturum açma, kullanıcı adı, şifre veya PIN'a ihtiyaç duymaz. ★ Grup Sohbeti. Signal tüm arkadaşlarınızla özel konuşmalar için şifreli gruplar oluşturmanıza olanak sağlar. Sadece şifrelenmiş mesajlar değil, Signal sunucusunun aynı zamanda üyelik listesi, grup başlığı veya grup simgesi gibi herhangi bir grup meta verisine de erişimi yoktur. ★ Hızlı. Signal protokolü mümkün olan en kısıtlı ortamlarda çalışmak üzere tasarlanmıştır. Signal kullanılarak, mesajlar arkadaşlarınıza anında teslim edilir. ★ Serbestçe konuşun - Hiçbir ücret olmadan, şehir genelinde yaşayan ya da dünyanın öbür ucundaki insanlarla kristal berraklığında telefon görüşmeleri yapın. (Uygulamanın bazı özellikleri internet bağlantısı gerektirir, veri ücreti uygulanabilir. Detaylar için operatörünüzle iletişime geçin.) Signal henüz tablet ile uyumlu değil, ancak daha büyük ekranlar için çalışmalarımız sürüyor ve gelecekteki bir sürümde bu destek eklenecektir! Destek, sorularınız veya daha fazla bilgi için, lütfen bu adresi ziyaret edin: http://support.whispersystems.org Daha fazla ayrıntı için: http://www.whispersystems.org/#encrypted_texts Kaynak kodu: https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android

report.summary: Check if Identical Publickey is send back at keyexchange
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hello there i noticed that in SMSSecure (i know where i am) there is kind of a glitch that, if you send out a key-exchange message to a non-SMSSecure user and sayed User forwards you that exact Message, the communication is afterwards shown to be encrypted which it most-likely is but with the own publickey which will result in more gibberish being send to the user. I am not sure if this affects Signal too, which it probably won't as the server automatically checks if sayed user has indeed Signal installed but a basic routine that checks if the send back publickey at key-exchange is indeed not identical to ones own publickey would be appreciated. Truth be told i am by no means a Cryptographer and can not estimate how trivial if at all such a routine would be to be implemented and even if this is something you consider important as it is a probably a rather rare occasion. I am just forwarding this to the crypto-guys which created the underlying protocol in the first place Greetings, Henry Kratom

report.summary: Overview of existing groups on contacts list
report.label: None yet
report.description: Whenever I want to sent a Signal message to more then one person, I need to setup a new group (btw: which is not the best UX imho, a more email like way might be better with being able to have many TO or CC recipients). I already have about a dozen groups now. Unlike the single Signal contacts, that are visible when I tap on the "write new message" button there is no overview of currently existing groups. There is only the initial history of recent messages but for not so often used groups these vanish there quickly and are then hard to find. Maybe there should be an extra tab on the contacts list overview. Or just all groups listed in between the Signal lists and SMS contacts would do too.

report.summary: The landscape compose window seems to have old UI
report.label: None yet
report.description: Open a chat; start typing in portrait mode; rotate the landscape mode. The very elegant UI with vibrant colors and well-laid out features disappears and is replaced with a paragraph box and a plain grey button. I'm not sure if this is intentional, but it did stand out to me as being odd.

report.summary: Use Signal without needing a phone #
report.label: None yet
report.description: Id like to be able to use signal on my wifi tablet without needing a phone #. Also, requiring a user to sign up with a unique identifier like a phone number seems to be like the first obvious identifier we would not want to require a user to submit if we are interesting in anonymity. Snowden talks about unique identifier databases. Bleep allows account creation with just a key pair. My request is not to require the user to submit identification information on a device that tracks their physical location, can be pinpointed by a stingray, and is most likely directly linked to their billing records. It also makes it a pain to keep a signal account portable when a user changes phone numbers. If a user wants to submit their phone number so that their contacts can locate them that way, fine, but as a requirement its a total game killer.

report.summary: Ripple Integration
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hi The guardianproject develops an ecosystem called Ripple. Ripple is used to define actions in apps that trigger when the owner of the phone gets in danger and pushes a panic button. SMSSecure for example hides itself when the panic button is triggered. It would be nice if Signal also would support this (hiding/locking the app, sending predefined messages to trusted contacts etc.) https://guardianproject.info/2016/01/12/panickit-making-your-whole-phone-respond-to-a-panic-button/

report.summary: Group messages are imported incorrectly from backup
report.label: None yet
report.description: I just did a factory reset and imported a plaintext backup. Then I noticed that a group I belong to shows only my own messages. All messages from other members are displayed in their individual conversations, not in the group they were originally sent to. Before the reset I made a plaintext backup and left the group. After the reset I imported the backup and had another member add me to the group again. New messages are displayed correctly, it's just the history from the backup that's slightly messed up. After noticing the problem I tried deleting all conversations and importing the backup again but the group history is still spread out across the conversations of the group members. Here is the link to the debug log submitted after the second import: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/cc20a61ee143dca2e113 I am also using the Signal Desktop beta. The registered devices seem to keep their own version of the history, even if you re-register, so obviously I did not have to import a backup there. All messages in the group and the conversations with individual contacts are displayed properly on my desktop machines. 👍 1

report.summary: Unregistered contacts don't disappear in groups
report.label: None yet
report.description: If a user unregisteres from Signal but did not leave a group, the user will stay in this group forever and you will get an error for every message you send to that group. I suggest that the all groups of a user should be automatically updated when he unregisters. There are many similar issues but not the same I think (#4550 , #2408 , WhisperSystems/Signal-Desktop#448). I fear that this might be an issue for the server because the clients shouldn't do this(?)

report.summary: Group messages partially delivered on poor network conditions
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hi @moxie0, on poor network conditions I often see that Signal indicates a failed delivery while some group members have received the message. Signal does not indicate which group member have received the message and which not. Re-sending leads to some group members receiving the message with multiple copies. In order to avoid such issues it should be possible to implement a solution based on the following principle: Indicate the server that a message to x group members is prepared to be sent Transfer all encrypted messages (for each participant) to the server The server waits until messages for each participant have been received The server delivers the messages Found with Signal 3.9.1.

report.summary: Signal doesn't resync known contacts
report.label: None yet
report.description: This is a duplicate of #4338 as this issue was already closed. See also maybe related issues I pointed out there. In short: If Signal already "knows" phone numbers of contacts, it doesn't resync with the phone contacts in case they're deleted or changed. I had for some reason multiple local phone contacts. To get rid of them, I deleted all my contacts from my phone and resynced them with DavDroid from my server. Since then Signal hasn't changed any of my contacts to add them as a Signal user. I'm running Signal 3.9.1 on Android 5.1.1 (CM 12.1) on a rooted device. It seems that Signal doesn't check the contacts anymore for already known numbers. Things I tried: Sync Signal via Settings -> Accounts; refresh contacts in Signal itself. When I display only Signal contacts, none of the former Signal contacts are shown. In fact only my own contact shows up. I can also confirm that this happened on a non-rooted Samsung Galaxy S4 mini running Android 4.4 and Signal 3.9.1. There the contacts had been deleted and resynced with Google. The only "solution" which helped to add Signal users in contacts again was to reinstall the app.

report.summary: Stop preventing people from sending texts when update is required
report.label: None yet
report.description: I'm regularly outside of data zones but would still like to communicate with people. Especially when not it's an emergency. It's happened a couple of times now that Signal prevents me from sending a text when an update is required and I'm without access to the internet. This is pretty poorly thought out. It also just blocks the message from being sent - you only see the warning on the inbox list, rather than on the message list - without giving any indication why the message wasn't sent (when looking at the message thread). This is for ordinary messages to people who don't use Signal and thus don't have encrypted texts. Instead of preventing the message being sent, how about warning the user that their signal app is insecure every time they try updating the message.

report.summary: Reinstall no contacts, groups broken
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hi, I factory reset my phone and installed Signal... and I reinstalled Signal multiple times now. The registration process is without problem... If I don't set Signal as the default SMS app, it shows no contacts whatsoever, allthough I resynced every possible account on the phone multiple times. If I set Signal as the default SMS app, it shows every contact twice (once from the google account and once from the whatsapp account, I think), allthough the rest of the phone handles identical entries without a problem. Also Contacts who write me still appear as phone numbers only and not in any way with a name, neither in groups nor in the chat overview nor in single chats. In either case: Groups where I am part of pop up when someone writes something in them, but they have cryptic names in popups (textsecure_group!1c20d...) and are named Unnamed Group inside the App. I can't reply in these groups, the keyboard dosn't even open. Also showing Group Members gives an empty Popup. This is by far not the first time I have Killer Issues with Textsecure/Signal (broken chats that can't be resolved, Contacts Syncing, allways broken Groups after reinstall (yes this is by far not the first time I'm having that issue, just the completely broken contacts are my main Issue right now)), Which saddens me because this is otherwise just an awesome Product and with Desktop support would replace 2 other messaging apps at once for me (of which I have about 5 at the moment). I seriously believe there are enough people that sent you debug logs and everything on similiar or the same issues, but if you need some I can provide them... with or without SMS enabled. Debug Log: https://gist.github.com/301d3f67764d531ced2e

report.summary: Lock Signal with passphrase and fingerprint
report.label: None yet
report.description: I've been using TextSecure/Signal for a while now and want to get more involved with the project. I figured adding fingerprint sensor app unlock support for the Android app would be a good first project. Before jumping into implementation, I found Issue #4439, where someone requested fingerprint app unlock as an alternative to passphrase, which was closed as wontfix. Was the reasoning for rejecting this feature request due to feature parity with iOS, placing trust in the OS's fingerprint store and authentication, privacy or security concerns, or software testing concerns? I'm not sure if the reasoning from Issue #420 significantly intrudes on the security levels I suggest below, especially when combined with exponential delays on failed attempts and database wipe after too many failed attempts within a period of time. This comes down to giving the user a choice of convenience and security, which I assume is why the no-passphrase option has not been removed yet. I was wondering if I implemented fingerprint app unlock if the Open Whisper team would be interested. Requiring both a passphrase and fingerprint is more secure than either one. In a public setting with wandering eyes, a fingerprint is more secure than a passphrase. Fingerprint sensor support would also allow quicker message checking while keeping Signal in a lock-after-5 minutes state. Here's what I was thinking of adding to the Settings menu always unlocked unlock with passphrase unlock with fingerprint or passphrase require passphrase every X hours (passphrase would be required after 3 fingerprint unlock attempts, and after any device reboot) unlock with passphrase and fingerprint (requires both to unlock the phone every time it is locked) erase all conversation history after Y failed unlock attempts (any combination of fingerprint and passphrase) Signal would use the Android Fingerprint API, using whatever fingers are registered with the OS.

report.summary: In conversation, make the typing cursor the same color as the contact's color
report.label: None yet
report.description: When tapping into a conversation, the cursor in the typing area matches the pretty signal blue for both secure and normal SMS contacts. I think it'd be a nice touch to have the cursor color match the contact's color. I know this wouldn't be a high priority issue at all but it would be low-hanging fruit for someone who does android programming and wanted to start getting involved with signal development.

report.summary: Transfer sms to new phone

Have also testet creating an export on N5x. Same issue there.. Cannot find any backup file and app does not say where its stored..

report.summary: Signal disappears from Recent Apps list
report.label: None yet
report.description: I can only get to Signal by opening from my home screen favorite/shortcut menu. It is never available in the Recent Apps list. Reproduce: Close all recent apps Open Chrome Press Home Open Signal Press Recent Apps Recent Apps list appears with Chrome. Signal scales/resizes down to fit, but then disappears. If I close all apps and open just Signal, when I press Recent Apps my app list is empty. This may be related to #1037 and is probably related to #3172. Neither describe this exact issue. Could be an unintended result of a workaround for #3172? report.summary: Cannot reply to contact who just joined Signal
report.label: None yet
report.description: I cannot reply to a contact who joined Signal yesterday using Signal-Android. I can receive encrypted messages just fine, but Signal-Android does not find the user on the server: The input bar reads "Send unsecured SMS" and there is no option to reset the encrypted connection. A lock is shown next to the messages I received from the contact, and the messages sync correctly to Signal-Desktop, so the encrypted connection seems functional. It seems that the registration is a bit mucked up, though. When I try to reply with Signal-Desktop, I get the following lines in the log: PUT https://textsecure-service-ca.whispersystems.org:4433/v1/messages/+[REDACTED]838 PUT https://textsecure-service-ca.whispersystems.org:4433/v1/messages/+[REDACTED]838 404 Error SendMessageNetworkError: Number is not registered. Failed to create or send message Error at chrome-extension://bikioccmkafdpakkkcpdbppfkghcmihk/js/libtextsecure.js:28:33 at chrome-extension://bikioccmkafdpakkkcpdbppfkghcmihk/js/libtextsecure.js:97:3 at chrome-extension://bikioccmkafdpakkkcpdbppfkghcmihk/js/libtextsecure.js:37835:3 I can't provide a meaningful log for Signal-Android because it doesn't even let me reply to the conversation. The (redacted) phone number never shows up in the log either. I can privately send you mine my contact's number if you want to investigate the registration on the server or anything.

report.summary: Different notifications on incoming text messages confusing
report.label: None yet
report.description: Signal 3.9.1 When I have no unread signal messages and I receive a message, I will get a notification which contains the sender's name and the message. When I have unread signal messages and I receive a message from a different contact, I will get a notification which shows "Most recent from: " and does not contain the text of the most recent message. Maybe this bothers me more than others due to my use case, but as I use a pebble which receives the text of notifications, this means that whenever I receive a message and I have another unread message, I will not be able to see the text of the newest message on my pebble. It will only receive the text of the new "Most recent from " message. I'd like for there to be a notification setting to turn off this "summary" notification.

report.summary: Bad Encrypted Message for one user in group chat
report.label: None yet
report.description: Added a user as a new contact during a group chat session as I wasn't receiving any messages in the group chat from them. I received about 4 successful messages from them, but after that every message is returning as Bad Encrypted Message. These return in a separate thread. My debug log is here: https://gist.github.com/bb031250ae878195ebd5

report.summary: LED notification does not work
report.label: None yet
report.description: I've run into a weird little issue : my phone's LED indicator is not working as part of "new message" notifications. The sound and the vibration do work, but the LED does not, which results in very poor usability : since without the blinking LED, having missed the initial sounds and vibrations, there is then no way to tell, by just looking at the phone, whether or not there are new messages except by unlocking the screen - so in order to not miss messages one has to constantly unlock the screen and check for a notification in the status bar. The LED used to work fine with text messages prior to the installation of Signal. It still works correctly with WhatsApp. Signal seems to be the only app where the LED is malfunctioning. Here's my debug log : https://gist.github.com/anonymous/a4338e57a0ee8ddfc0a3 . I submitted this issue as a support request (ID 1667) back on December 13, but have since despaired of getting any reply and so decided to create an issue here.

report.summary: Please clarify some of the "other" permissions
report.label: None yet
report.description: Comparing the permissions of Signal with other similar apps, they are pretty standard, but under the other section there are some that raise the eyebrows, and I would appreciate some clarifications about their usage: Signal Private Messenger Open Whisper Systems Version 3.10.0 can access: access Bluetooth settings close other apps draw over other apps modify system settings pair with Bluetooth devices read Google service configuration read your social stream set wallpaper toggle sync on and off write to your social stream Thanks in advance

report.summary: TOO_SHORT_AFTER_IDD
report.label: None yet
report.description: I've just noticed the error above in a friends log: cat.log

report.summary: App in background not polling new messages
report.label: None yet
report.description: Often time I have to open the app for Signal to poll new messages. Basically the app do not fetch for days and it is only when you manually open the app that it actually fetch all the messages. It happens on many devices, actually many android devices of my relatives. It happens more often with miui/xiaomi devices which is known to often kill background services for performances purposes. It happens since months and I thought it would be a common bug. Other app do get notifications.

report.summary: Phone Calls Fail When Calling via VPN

report.summary: Conversation list floating action button's symbol is ambiguous
report.label: None yet
report.description: The graphical symbol (pencil) of the floating action button in the conversation list doesn't make much sense. A pencil usually represents writing. But tapping that floating action button opens Signal's contact list (and is btw currently the only way to achieve that), which is not very intuitive. "Writing" in that context could be interpreted as e. g. a) writing a new message within an existing conversation (i. e. in the conversation list) or b) starting a new conversation (i. e. in the contact list). One the other hand, a plus sign ("+") represents adding, like in adding a new conversation. Within the context of the conversation list, I'm not aware of any other imaginable interpretations, so a plus sign is not ambiguous regarding its purpose. So in conclusion, I suggest that the pencil symbol is replaced by a plus sign. An alternative possibility would be using that "contacts" symbol pictured below (after all, tapping the button opens Signal's contact list). CC: @agrajaghh 👍 1

report.summary: Remove single '_' identifiers from java source.
report.label: None yet
report.description: Rename the conventional ignored exception variable name in catch clauses where they exist. i.e. prefer something like try { ... } catch (TException ignored) { } to try { ... } catch (TException _) { } These result in compile-time warnings under Java 8, and will be compile-time errors in Java 9. To reproduce: Build Signal-Android using a Java 8 SDK [1] [1] $ java -version java version "1.8.0_74" Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_74-b02) Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.74-b02, mixed mode)

report.summary: What happened to encrypted SMS fallback?
report.label: None yet
report.description: I just installed the latest Signal (3.9.1), and installed it on GFs phone as well. Then I text her and she didn't get my text until she turned her data on the next day. This used to work so well, especially in our country where mobile data is finite and very expensive and where we may not want to have our data enabled for fear of further tracking/random apps eating your cap. Sending messages over data is great and all I understand the metadata security implications of SMS but surely it is better to send metadata in the clear, and the message encrypted, than sending both in the clear? Seemed like a great way to backport encryption to older technologies. The other great thing about the app was that you could replace the shitty stock SMS apps that come with smartphones with this beautiful application and get encryption to people who have the same app, over data or SMS. I read over issue #2847 and they seemed to completely discount this whole user base and the above use cases... pretty sad. I don't want to have to go back to the shitty stock SMS app :(

report.summary: Does the string "Signal system database import" make any sense...?
report.label: None yet
report.description: The recent commit 25d7931 uses the string "Signal system database import is complete." (I am aware that @haffenloher just made the already existing string translatable and replaced "TextSecure" with "Signal" - so not pointing fingers). "Signal system database" doesn't make any sense to me, i. e. having "Signal" and "system" in the same expression imho contradicts itself. There are a) Signal's (encrypted) database and b) Android's central database for SMS/MMS, which is used by other messaging apps. What this string means to describe is the process of importing from (b) to (a), i. e. from the system database to Signal's database. So this really should read "System database import is complete.", correct? While I'm at it, I'd rather suggest "Import of the system's SMS/MMS database has been completed." (this assumes that this string is the text body of a dialog - more space for more detailed info available - while "Import complete" is the dialog's title) or "Import of system database completed." if something shorter is needed.

report.summary: Argentina phone number schemes
report.label: None yet
report.description: Non-international phone number are not supported (contact does not appears during a search) A mobile phone number can appear in multiple way here: +54 9 (area) (number) 0054 9 (area) (number) (area) 15 (number) (if inside Argentina, whatever the caller area code is) 15 (number) [if both numbers share the same area] Where "9" is the magic number for mobile (equivalent to the local "15) and "1" for land-lines "15" is the magic number for mobile (number) contains 6 to 8 digits (area) can (optionally?) be prefixed by a trunk code of value "0", eg: 223 == 0223, or 11 == 011 (don't know about the cases of the trunk code being mandatory) The area is somehow part of the number (since the number is registered for a unique and given area). But it can be omitted if calling from a device from the same area (similarly to the country code 54 which can be omitted if we call from a national device) Most contact's phone numbers are registered using the 4th scheme excepting contacts from other regions. The Android API already provides the country code. From this, it may be possible to know the area code (depending on the Android API?) From the above two it should be fairly easy to map phones number from one scheme to another. I don't know if heavy modifications are needed, but I could at least provide a PR to add test case. https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/blob/master/test/unitTest/java/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/util/PhoneNumberFormatterTest.java ? [edit] It seems that most of the country-specific logic should be handled by the libphonenumber, and more specifically https://github.com/googlei18n/libphonenumber/blob/master/java/libphonenumber/test/com/google/i18n/phonenumbers/data/PhoneNumberMetadataProtoForTesting_AR If it turns to be true, then what keeps the different notation to be understand as a unique contact?

report.summary: Question on iOS vs. Android
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hello, please apologize if my post is not appropriate here. I like Signal very much, I have installed it on both of my Phones - a Samsung phone on Android and on my iPhone. And I am really puzzled by the big differences in the app on both OS. I could even say that it almost looks like a different app. Here I would like to accent on 2 things: Some time ago, I had raised a question, that while speaking on Signal on my Android phone, it is not possible to put the Signal call on hold, in order to take the phone call. I have got an answer, that it is not possible. On my iPhone though, I was surprised, that this works! I was speaking on Signal, I received a phone call and I was able to take the phone call !! Security settings - I was pleased with the many security features offered on Android - it is possible to set a PIN code in order to access the app. I was also delighted about the option to set a number of messages to be kept, which I have set very low, so all the old messages simply go to /dev/zero Both these options are not available on iOS :-/ Even when I enter the settings, they look almost empty, compared to the numerous settings and options on Android... Can you please shortly comment on why it is like that ? Just asking out of curiosity... I hope that the app will further evolve on both platforms and will provide even more features! Thank you for providing this magnificent software for free!! I wish you all the best for the future!

report.summary: Possible bug in send() in RtpAudioSender.cpp
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description I tried to get Signal working on BlackBerry's Runtime for Android. Sadly voice calls only partially working. I can call other Signal users but they can't hear my voice. I'm getting a lot of sendto() failed! errors in /dev/log/main. After some further debugging I found that sendto() always fails with error 22 (EINVAL - invalid argument). As far as I understand the code the socket is already connected in RtpSocket.java so a send() should be enough in RtpAudioSender.cpp. I changed sendto() to send() and got voice calls working. I'm not sure if this is a BlackBerry specific issue cause it works with sendto() on pretty any Android device. Steps to reproduce Install Signal on a BlackBerry Install Cobalt's Google Apps follow the instructions on Cobalt's official Google Apps landing page. You need to install Google Account Manager, Blackberry Google ID and Google Play services the Google Play store itself is not needed. Patch and install Signal follow the instructions on How to patch Android Apps depending on Google Maps and Google Play Services. Call a another Signal user. Device info Model: BlackBerry Passport OS v10.3.2.2836 Android version: 4.3.0 Signal version: 3.13.0

report.summary: Signal forces 'so and so is on signal, say hey' messages over and over again after titanium backup restore

report.description: Bug description I've had to reinstall my phone (oneplus2), and I've used titanium backup to conduct that operation. Steps to reproduce install signal send a few messages make a backup of signal using titanium backup format phone / factory reset re-root, install old rom (i'm using stock oneplus2 roms) install titanium backup restore apps, or even just signal by itself resulting scenario is signal re-pushing welcome messages to you forever. report.summary: Request for enhancement: Autoclose Signal after set inactivity
report.label: None yet
report.description: I would like to present one of our use cases for Signal (on Android): We use the app for sensitive information exchange, but would not only like the communication safe on the communication channel side, but also protected from people having access to our phones. Therefore we have set a password and set the inactivity time out to a low value. Often in a rush you might not be able to lock and close Signal and thus this is done automatically within a minute in our case. There are situations in reality where other people temporarily have access to your phone and therefore locking the app is very important ... Now we would find it very useful additional to the automatic lock after inactivity we could also set an option to automatically close Signal. In theory Signal offers everything to achieve what we need to be sufficiently secure, if there was not bug 3172, which leaves a screenshot in the recent app overview of your communication in some cases on Android >5, which happens regularly to us. An autoclose feature would also work around that problem, as the app is automatically closed after a set time out if we forget to close it. Automatically closing is very sensible from our point of view as it exactly does what automatically locking does: Making sure as much information as possible stays private ... an open signal windows in the recent apps overview is some tiny bit of information we would like to avoid automatically by setting a timeout. Of course if sensitive information exchange happens the user should be sensible enough to make sure he locks and closes the app, but in reality all of us are human and there are situations where auto locking and auto closing saves you a lot of trouble. I think this also fits well with idea of signal being as simple as possible to use. I agree technology can not compensate stupidity of people, but that's not what I am requesting. Furthermore it would compensate bug 3172 really well, as this would not have to rely on the ROM following the rules.

report.summary: [Feature Request] Internal "secure" popup keyboard.
report.label: None yet
report.description: Hi All, I was thinking that it would be cool to have a popup keyboard that opens in the app only. This would not be a keyboard app for android, really just a series of buttons that are displayed in the app that would allow the user to type "seriously secure content" without being tracked. I know that we could find a keyboard that "doesn't track anything" but it seems much more secure to have a internal keyboard that isn't a keyboard at all. Even if they say they don't track, you can't really be sure, plus, for most of my other activities, I enjoy the auto-correct and predictiveness of Google. Even most of my messages, I don't really have an issue with Google storing the data they store. But if I did want to send something I was worried about Google seeing, having a quick button I could click to open up a keyboard to enter a quick message would be amazing. Websites have done this for years, typically older government sites. They would have a little popup keyboard that you would use your mouse to select they keys to ensure a keylogger wasn't recording your social security number. Seems like a good idea to me, what do you think? I have: [ x] searched open and closed issues for duplicates [ x] read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports 👎 1

report.summary: Optional periodic check for new messages (when push isn't working reliably)
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description Signal should fall back to periodic update checks when GCM Push doesn't work Steps to reproduce Tried installing Signal on a Motorola RAZR M, with Android 4.4.2 I have a friend with the same model, who also has the same issue with Signal I have followed all the steps here: http://support.whispersystems.org/hc/en-us/articles/213190487-Why-is-there-a-delay-in-receiving-messages- The RAZR M does not have any options for "Phone specific optimisation" When the screen is off, push notifications do not work for Signal messages (but do work for SMS) Only when the screen is unlocked, and the Signal app is opened, new message notifications arrive Expected behaviour There should be a manual option to perform the same routine as opening the app to check for new messages at a defined interval, say every 10 minutes. Messages do arrive, but only when the app is opened. To stop impact to other users for whom GCM Push works properly, this setting should be off by default This would mean that Signal messages are at least delivered eventually, rather than only when opening the app and manually refreshing Device info Model: Motorola RAZR M Android version: 4.4.2 Signal version: 3.13.1

report.summary: App reading SMS when Signal is locked
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description I am not sure if this is a vulnerability, if it's a bug or a "feature". When using Signal as a default SMS app and enable the locked option, as far as I know, no one should be able to access any received message. However, if you have any two factor-authentication enable on Google (using Google as an example) and try to login to your Google account, you will receive an SMS and Google will automatically read the SMS and authenticate you, without any need of manually having to unlock Signal, copy the authentication code and paste it to Google's prompt. This should probably work with any app that will automatically read any SMS received to authenticate any 2 second-authentication code. This concerns me, because if I have any type of malware listening to my SMS app, it will be able to read any message I receive without worrying if Signal is locked or not. Steps to reproduce Remove your Google account from your Android settings. Make sure Signal is locked and is your default SMS app. Login to your Google Account. Wait for the SMS. Google will automatically authenticate you. Device info Samsung Galaxy S5 running Cyanogen lastest nightly build of KLTE. ** Signal Version: 3.13.1

report.summary: Cryptic failure toast when USERTRUST cert disabled
report.label: None yet
report.description: If the USERTRUST RSA ssl cert Signal uses is disabled in Settings -> Security -> Trusted Certificated, Signal correctly fails to register. However, the message is a generic server connection failure... Technically correct, practically not very helpful. To be honest, I recently disabled all the certs on my phone and started running apps one by one and approving only what needs approving. So far, not a single app did too well in these regards. A few even failed silently... Regardless, even if it's not worth improving on, I figured I should at least put it out there just in case someone runs into some obscure but related issues. I also saw the last few commits touched some elliptic curve cipher related stuff so this might actually be useful one day ;)

report.summary: Repeatable builds
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates Description My goal is to verify that the APK distributed on Google Play is executing the code at the commit of the release tag on GitHub. Even though I trust OWS to publish the untampered code, they could be compelled to alter it without revealing it, and it is better to know than to assume. To do the verification, I'm looking at the hash of each file in the APK I get from Google Play and comparing it with the hash of the APK I built myself. In build.gradle a timestamp is populated as a BuildConfig field at build time. This field has millisecond accuracy and is used to expire the binary after 90 days. Due to it changing during every build, classes.dex in the APK has a different hash, so it's impossible to verify the integrity of the code. Proposal I'd like to submit a PR to: change the timestamp to be granular only to the day (1458190800000ms). be replaceable by an environment or system variable. This would allow for easy APK verification. The signing date of the Play APK can be used to determine the build date which can then be replaced during a verification build. The timestamp can still be used to determine when 90 days have gone by and a build has expired. Risks The risk of this feature regressing in the future is fairly high due to the external nature of the verification. This could be mitigated by a build step that performs the verification, or reduced through good commenting. The code I'm using for verification is available here. Signal version: 3.14.1, and master at time of filing. 👍 2

report.summary: Signal should open a new tab for each clicked link
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: [x ] searched open and closed issues for duplicates [ x] read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description Android apps can choose whether their links open a new tab or overwrite any previous tab the app had opened. Signal should so the former, but does the latter. For example, if a friend sends a link to a newspaper article about how awesome end to end encryption is, and then while I'm reading it I get a message from a restaurant asking me to click a link to confirm my reservation, doing so will overwrite the tab where I was reading the article, requiring me to go back to that conversation, click it again, and then find my place again. This is annoying, and sometimes hard to anticipate (who remembers how they opened a tab four hours ago?) Steps to reproduce click a link in a message you received use the app switcher button to switch back to signal click a different link in a message you received Device info Model: Google/LG Nexus 5X Android version: 6.0.1 Signal version: 3.14.2 Solution You need to set EXTRA_CREATE_NEW_TAB. see https://developer.android.com/reference/android/provider/Browser.html#EXTRA_CREATE_NEW_TAB for details. I guess if some people find the current behavior preferable, this could be a configuration option, though I really think this is almost always unexpected behavior. I could send a pull request, but: I don't have an appropriate dev environment set up, and so would have to do so without testing, which makes me nervous. I can't actually find where Signal is calling out to the browser.

report.summary: Record and send audio ("software walkie talkie") for using in bad connectivity conditions
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Enhancement description There are many sharing options in Signal, including sending of images and videos taken from camera or audio files, recorded by another application, but there is no convenient way to send and receive (play in-app) audio recordings, recorded only with the microphone. This is a very useful feature in bad connectivity or harsh audio environments, where live audio call is not an option (a very notable case being a warzone or aftermath of a natural disaster). There are also many markets such as Spain where people use this function on a daily basis. If the description is not evident enough, try to think of it as a "software walkie talkie", which allows the first Signal user to only press a button in the application (like "push-to-talk" button on a walkie talkie) and it starts recording the audio, which is then compressed with a suitable speech codec and sent via Signal to the receiving user. In this way the talk is not real-time, but it allows for disturbances in the connectivity between the two users and it also allows the second user to listen to the message repeatedly in case of loud audio environment on any side of the conversation. ps: Maybe TextSecure-Server would be a better repository to post this enhancement to, but it doesn't seem too live, and I haven't been able to found the Signal-Server one... If it's necessary, I'll repost this elsewhere, just let me know where.

report.summary: fallback to a different SMS provider than builtin SMS carrier
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description Since I do not have a phone carrier plan, I use signal to send and receive messages over Wifi connections. This works because I have a VoIP provider with which I was able to go through the voice-based registration procedure (and thank you so much for that!). However, to send and receive SMS messages, I use a different app, which works pretty well. In fact, during the registration process, I did receive the SMS confirmation message - i just wasn't able to use it because Signal didn't intercept it. But that's fine as well because I could work around the problem. My main concern at this point is that I need to consciously switch between my SMS and Signal apps, based on whether or not I know that the user has Signal at all. In fact, I think there's a usability issue there, even for regular user: if Signal has trouble sending SMS messages (e.g. problem with the SIM card, connectivity issues), how does it tell the user? From my point of view here, Signal tries to send the message and I get the "bouncing 3 dots" forever, even though there's no SIM card on the phone and this will never succeed. What I would like would be for Signal to be able to talk to other apps to send and receive insecure SMS messages. I am not sure i clearly understand how the insecure fallback works right now - it doesn't feel like Signal uses the builtin messaging app but talks to the SMS subsystem of Android on itself. Could it be possible to fallback to some other SMS provider? I guess this also applies to competing protocols like Whatsapp or Telegram: what if my contact is not using signal? Could I still use Signal as a unified messaging app? (and coincidentally invite my poor Whatsapp or Telegram user to join Signal!) Note that other apps would need support for such process, of course. I have opened an issue for my specific app (michaelkourlas/voipms-sms-client#55) but I guess there would need to be such systems in place for this to work with Telegram or Whatsapp or whatever... Finally, I understand if you close my feature request as out of scope, but please do consider at least the case where the sim card is misplaced, removed, or the phone is in airplane mode. Usability could be improved at that level. At least having a timeout (or a shorter one, if there is one already) would improve the situation here. Steps to reproduce remove your SIM card register a SIP account with SMS support (e.g. at https://voip.ms/) install an app to manage SMS in Android (e.g. https://github.com/michaelkourlas/voipms-sms-client) try to send an insecure message in Signal Actual result: the message never gets sent and gets stuck in the "bouncing 3 dots" state forever (or at least, I have a few messages stuck in that state since saturday, so 48h+) Expected result: detect there is no SIM card and fail, or offer some configuration option to send messages through another messaging app Screenshots The above screenshot shows Signal functioning normally for secure messages, but shows the last message stuck in the "three bouncing dots" state for 3 minutes. Earlier in the history, there are two more messages stuck in that state from saturday (not shown in screenshot). Device info Device: HTC One S4 ("Ville") Android version: 5.1.1 (Cyanogenmod 12.1-20160323-NIGHTLY-Ville) Signal version: 3.15.2 Link to debug log https://gist.github.com/5b0303234463bc3ce4146f9bbec802e4

report.summary: Moving signal from one phone to another causes issues.
report.label: None yet
report.description: Bug description Last week I was travelling. Prior to my trip I had asked a question on the Signal site about migrating my session to my old phone (which would not matter too much if it were lost or stolen). The response I got was: You can install Signal on your other phone. Any new installation of Signal will generate new keys. However, it doesn't seem to be as simple as this. Steps to reproduce This explains my pre-travel actions: Install signal for android on phone1. Use signal for a while. Partake in private and group messages. Remove sim card from phone1 and install in phone2. Install signal on phone2. At this point, I am on the road with phone2. If you message people, they are informed that my keys have changed, which is fine. However, if other people post in a group chat that you were involved in on phone1, then the group is named Unnamed group on phone2 and the message entry box is un-tappable. You see messages come in, but you are unable to send messages. Then I returned home, and replaced the sim card into phone1. Now I cannot message anyone. The messages have a red message next to them saying Failed to send and Tap for details. When you tap, you see ( i ) Some issues need your attention and Failed to send. There is are-send` button, but it doesn't help in this case. Expected Outcome Signal should work on multiple devices per account (and it would be nice if it worked on tablets too). I think the issues I outline are because each user is expected to have exactly one keypair. This would be fine if there were a way to share a keypair between more than one device, or if Signal allowed one account to have multiple key-pairs. Maybe this design decision relates to the fact that a phone number can be active in only one device at a time? I also note that signal still works on phone1 which has no SIM card inserted. Not sure if that is desired behaviour(?). I'm not sure what I should do to get signal working again, please advise. Thanks

report.summary: Sent videos shouldn't take up extra space on internal memory
report.label: None yet
report.description: Ever since I installed Android M on my Moto G3 I've had problems not filling my internal memory by accident, because Play Music now refuses to put my music on my SD-card. Ordinarily I can handle this quite well, with one exception.. Signal keeps using all the internal space, because everytime I send a video the app creates a duplicate of the file *_inside *_of Signal and I can't help but ask: Why? Why would I ever need a copy of my video inside of Signal? If you send a video you already have it on your phone, so why make another copy? The obvious explanation is that that way you know which video you sent, but really, can't you just add a file name instead? I think this behavior would be fine if I could put Signal on my SD-card, or if Signal could somehow only save transferred files on the SD-card, but in a world where internal space is scarce I think this is a really stupid design decision. Yes, I know about the feature that trims conversations and yes I know I can just delete the video from Signal after sending the file. But come on guys, that shouldn't be necessary!

report.summary: Enhancement: Only open keyboard in contact list when long-pressing the Compose button
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports I've always found it unnerving that the keyboard always pops up when opening the contact list (and I'm sure I'm not the only one). Nine out of ten times, I'll immediately close the keyboard. At the same time, I understand that this behavior has its purpose. So in order to make everybody happy, I suggest a small (but quite elegant imho) change that additionally is completely in line with Android's (i. e. Marshmallow's) own behavior regarding e. g. the All Apps button (the button that opens Android's app drawer): Tapping the Compose (i. e. pencil) button opens the contact list (but not the keyboard), Long-pressing the Compose button opens the contact list AND the keyboard. Ok, that's it. My suggestion.

report.summary: Read notifications
report.label: None yet
report.description: I would like to have Signal display read notifications to contacts that I choose. I have read the lengthy discussion in #957 about read receipts but since this is over 2 years old, I would like to reopen the discussion. From my point of view, having a feature that transmits information (like when a message was read) in an app that is about communication (i.e. the transmission of information) is a good thing. Whether to make this feature on/off by default or opt-in/opt-out is obviously debatable. My personal opinion is that I'd probably like it to be opt-out on a per contact basis, but to not change the current behavior for people from how it currently is, it would probably be more sensible to have Signal ask the question once per contact (when you start a new conversation) unless a default setting is set in the settings section. Even if the feature is delivered as off by default and has to be manually enabled, it would be a big improvement over the status-quo. Because (and I cannot stress this enough after reading through the discussion in #957) having a minority restrict the choices of a majority is the opposite of freedom and democracy and it seems to me these are among the most important things that free secure messaging is trying to protect.

This isn't harmful, it's just stupid on my behalf :-) If I'm the kind of person who cares about verifying keys (which is rare I grant!) this could also make it easy for me to see whose keys I haven't verified yet. 👍 5

report.summary: [Feature request] Support offline mesh network messaging
report.label: None yet
report.description: I have: [x ] searched open and closed issues for duplicates [x ] read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Feature Request: Offline mesh network messaging. Implement an option to use an offline mesh message network like e.g. firechat. firechat and the like use the phones Wi-Fi and Bluetooth antennas to transmit messages, calls and files without connection to cell towers or Wi-Fi. if more people are using it, it can relay messages through other users to the recipient (less server load). it could be nice if signal could send messages like: is local mesh-network available? yes: use no: ↓ is signal message possible? ues: use, no ↓ use sms. Why usercase1: privacy This will give great privacy reassurance. if you are within range to use a local mesh-network you can communicate "offline" with less chance of mass surveillance. Firechat was used for this reason during the umbrella revolution in Hong Kong for democracy and free speach. usercase2: travel/mass gatherings If you are travelling (to a country where you don't have a mobile plan or in a place without coverage (plane or underground train)) you can use local mesh-network messaging to contact people and to find people in the crowd of a festival etc. This would give great convenience, privacy, communication redundancy and save on you money on your mobile plan.
